talk.start.para: —I find it almost axiomatic when coalition members enter debate about economic conditions, the government's record, economic measures that the government have taken in the budget or history in relation to the Labor Party that there is an absolute correlation between the relative amount of time people have spent only in government and their level of ignorance about what happened prior to that, when Labor were in government. If there were not that direct correlation then the debate here might be on a sounder footing, because speaker after speaker, in being ignorant of and blinkered to what actually happened over the 13 years of the Labor government, has no real, proper comparator.

speech.para: The member for Moncrieff alleged that it would be impossible for Labor to put forward a plan which was based on a pretty accurate scrutiny of the budget's current measures. We know that the budget is only about one-third of the government's total spending in any one year now; the other two-thirds are announced in different ways. Here is an opposition, one would be led to believe if you followed that argument, that (1) does not have the capacity to scrutinise what was being done and (2) does not have the ability to assess the different government programs that are on offer and to decide that a Labor government would have different priorities to the coalition. It should be axiomatic that we would have different approaches—and therefore different priorities and different spending programs—and that therefore the outcome in government would be different if Labor were to get in.

I remember the former member for Blaxland saying quite truly that when governments change the country changes. No truer statement could have been made; think of what has happened over the last eight years. Those people who support the coalition are quite happy with most of the things the coalition has done in government and they are happy with this budget—a series of election bribes, to the order of $52 billion. And it is quite reasonable that those people who fundamentally support the Labor Party in its approach, its priorities and its way of putting programs into place would have an opposite view.

When we come to the Tax Laws Amendment (Personal Income Tax Reduction) Bill 2004 and what the Treasurer has proposed to do in terms of tax scales, if the proper comparison is in place—a measured comparison between what the coalition has done in eight years and what Labor did in the previous 13 years and therefore, axiomatically, what Labor might therefore be more likely to do when it comes back to office—a number of things should be apparent. The first is that, over Labor's 13 years in office, from memory—and I was there for most of it, assisting the former member for Blaxland during the nine years when he was Treasurer and then for the four years when he was Prime Minister; I only really missed out on two, so I have a fair background for remembering what was done—there were four major sets of tax changes attempting to address bracket creep. In the absence of the Labor government and its determination over 13 years to index the taxation rates, this government over eight years, in this budget and every other one that the member for Higgins has done, has determined that the tax rates would not be indexed from now into the future.

The most surprising element of the figures is that what was presented on budget night was tax figures and spending proposals not over a triennium but over a quinquennium; not over three years but over five years. If you take it from now out to five years can anyone honestly believe that (1) the coalition will still be in power then and (2) these projections will be right five years on? You would have some trouble trying to believe projections even three years on. If you in fact look at history and make a comparison between what was said in 1998 by this Liberal government and what happened over the full operation of the government, you will see that they made a promise. I do not think it was a core promise, because it was honoured in the other way. It must have been a non-core promise from the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. They promised that the effective marginal tax rate for ordinary, middle-income people would not be above 30 per cent. One could argue that, as the member for Blaxland, I am a bit biased in regard to this. If I hazarded a guess that throughout the whole of the eight years of the government's operation they would not once in any single year—although they had guaranteed it and said that was their goal—deliver an effective marginal tax rate of 30 per cent for 80 per cent of the Australian people, people would say: `He's biased. He's been around. He's just a Labor lackey.'

I just happened to come across a little bit of an argument from someone else, someone whom I think could be readily said is not a Labor lackey, given his past. He might say something that is useful. This person, on page 110 of a book called Tax: Facts Fiction and Reform—which was put out by the Australian Tax Research Foundation; it was their research study No. 41—argued that, although this had been a goal in 1998 when the new tax system was proposed by the Treasurer, in fact, like lots of non-core promises, it has never been achieved in a single year of the coalition's operation. Who was this person who may or may not be a doubtful contributor? I have to tell you that it was Neil Warren—not a friend of the Labor Party, I would think, based on his past contributions; certainly close to the coalition. This one fundamental tenet was argued in 1998 as a goal. But wait: it was restated just at budget time. It is restated year after year. The member for Higgins, after doing the computations of what happened in 1996 and 1998 and 1999 and after counting it up year by year, told us when he introduced this bill:

quote.para: The tax cuts in this bill will mean that more than 80 per cent of taxpayers will have a top tax rate of 30 per cent or less over the forward estimates period.

speech.para: If you believe that, you may as well believe something that is completely contrary to all past experience, as Neil Warren has pointed out: you would also believe what the member for Moncrieff and other members of the coalition argue—that Labor left $96 billion worth of debt, all Labor generated, and that this government, shoulder to the wheel, has tried to address that. The reality is the member for Bennelong's recession of 1982-83 created an enormous problem for the Australian people. The member for Bennelong was a distinguished Treasurer: distinguished against all other Treasurers of the Commonwealth in being able to achieve a trifecta that no other Treasurer, try as they might, was able to achieve. As a single example from this man, he had the trifecta of double-digit unemployment, double-digit inflation and double-digit interest rates. No-one else has had that triple. I grant now that we have single digits over all of that economic territory. That is exceptional. But it is on the basis of the economic performance and record of the Labor Party, and indeed the changes in Australia's tax system brought in in the 13 years that Labor was in government, that the fundamental foundation of the new Australian economy was laid.

talk.start.para: —Those who sometimes pass the time in country Victoria can laugh at this. However, it is fundamentally true. The old Australian economy that Labor was faced with when it came to power in 1983 was completely renovated. That happened for a very simple reason: Australia's problems had become so difficult and so great with the collapse in the terms of trade in 1985-86 that something had to be done—and something of a major order. What we see here for a period of years running forward into the future is a set of proposals that will not fundamentally change the Australian tax scales. What did this Treasurer do in relation to it a few years ago? He increased the tax-free threshold from $5,200 to $6,000. What is the proposition here? Over two tranches, there are two sets of changes to the point at which those tax scales come into operation. Where they come into operation the top rate is still 47 per cent. That top rate was introduced by who? Labor. Labor brought in the top marginal rate of 47 per cent. What was the coalition rate during the period 1982-83, when the member for Bennelong was Treasurer?
—Sixty per cent.

—The member for Lowe quite correctly answers the question: 60 per cent. Prior to that, for the whole of the Menzies period it was 66 per cent. Labor brought down the top marginal rate. There is no change to the top marginal rate here, and commentator after commentator quite rightly says this Treasurer has squibbed it when it comes to making fundamental change. It would have cost, as Mr Saunders pointed out in the Australian Financial Review on 13 May, $4 billion to really try to address this problem. None of that $4 billion has been used to take the top marginal rate from 47 per cent to 40 per cent and to make some inroads into the disjunction between the corporate rate of 30 per cent and the top marginal rate of 47 per cent. There is no real reform and no real fundamental change in what has happened here. What we have is an adjusting of the scales. It is giving back most of the bracket creep that has been there since 1996 but it is giving it back eight years too late.

speech.para: Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 9.00 p.m—
—What a shame!
—I am assuming that the member for Blaxland has not concluded his speech.
—Absolutely right, Mr Speaker.
—I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I am most aggrieved that that very erudite presentation by the member for Blaxland has been truncated by the adjournment. Nonetheless, member for Blaxland, I will press on.
—I can recognise the member for Blaxland, at the member for Holt's expense, if he would like.

—Mr Speaker, I would like to talk about the many families in my electorate of Holt and the city of Casey who looked at the 2004 budget with some level of expectation that the federal government would fix the plunging rate of bulk-billing in my electorate—from 91.7 per cent to 76.1 per cent in three years—and that they would be able to access a general practitioner and not have to wind up in the emergency department of the Dandenong Hospital, which in fact is happening. We have had an 11.5 per cent increase in presentations to the emergency department of Dandenong Hospital over the last couple of years as a consequence of many people not being able to access a fully bulk-billing doctor. They also had an expectation that their children would not have to take out a mortgage to fund their tertiary education and they had some level of expectation of social infrastructure; for example, something like a Medicare office in the city of Cranbourne. After all, that is what they pay their taxes for.

speech.para: I regret to report to this House that their expectations were shattered by this very cynical budget that was brought down by the government. Let me tell you about what the budget meant for the working families of the electorate of Holt. It did not mean, as I said, that the bulk-billing rate would be fixed—the bulk-billing rate which had plunged from 91.7 per cent to 76.1 per cent in the space of three years. What I am being told by general practitioners and the Division of General Practice is that, in the space of the next five years, if some drastic measures are not taken, there will be no fully bulk-billing doctors in the area.

I will also address the issue of tax cuts. One would expect, given the magnitude of the tax cuts, that many working families in my electorate would have received a tax cut. Again, I regret to inform the House that 94 per cent of my electorate will receive no tax cut. The average weekly income of families in my electorate is $896. It is not like the electorate of Bennelong, which has an average income of $1,300 per week. The families in my electorate are struggling, working families who are working very hard to put their kids through school—working hard for their children's education—and to pay off their mortgage. What did they get? They did not get a tax cut. Ninety-four per cent of people in my electorate—

talk.start.para: —That is scandalous!
—I know—it is absurd! I would not believe it but, unfortunately, having done an analysis, 94 per cent of people in my electorate will not get a tax cut.

speech.para: I would also like to address the issue of doctor shortages, particularly one example—the Hallam Medical Group. This is a fully bulk-billing clinic. It has 8,500 people on the database and it is being managed by one doctor because she cannot get another doctor to help her out. One of the reasons that she is struggling with this is that we cannot get bulk-billing doctors out our way. As a consequence, she is having to turn away 20 patients a day from her medical practice.

One of the reasons that there is a struggle to find a GP is the lack of interest in working in a fully bulk-billing practice, when the same GP is likely to earn more in a partially or fully privatised practice. There were very few replies to Dr d'Argent, the doctor who is practising at that clinic. A few who had shown interest were overseas trained doctors. As their provider numbers are restricted, Dr d'Argent applied for an `area of need' consideration to the Department of Health and Ageing to get a provider number for an overseas trained doctor. This application was rejected.

The Dandenong Division of General Practice states that, in the city of Casey, for every one GP, there are 2,000 people to service. The recommended GP ratio is one GP for 1,400 people. Each area is judged on the flexible basis of demographics and population growth—yet Dr d'Argent cannot get a doctor to assist her. Twenty patients a day are being turned away.

Unfortunately, my time is very short, so I will not talk about the fact that we cannot get a Medicare office in the city of Cranbourne—which has a population of 30,000 people. What I will say is that the families in Holt have been cruelly let down by this budget. Ninety-four per cent of the people of Holt are not getting a tax cut. They have not had bulk-billing fixed in their area, they cannot access a fully bulk-billing GP, and they are winding up in the emergency department of the Dandenong hospital. This cruel hoax of a budget should be exposed for what it is: a deception on the working people of Holt.

talk.start.para: —Kangaroo Valley, in the electorate of Gilmore, is a spectacular little village located about half an hour's drive from Nowra. It has the spirit of a typical Aussie country town, and the values that such townspeople cherish is almost palpable. So, when I was asked to look at some essays the local schoolchildren had written on the contribution of Australians at home during World War 2, I thought that I should honour their efforts by reading them into the Hansard.

speech.para: I have selected four who won first prize and, with your permission, Mr Speaker, I would like to read some extracts. The first is from a year 3 student, Laura Kent. She says:

quote.para: I read books of how determined they were to win and I believe it.
They jumped out of the trenches shooting bullets and throwing shells even though they knew they would die or get wounded.
ANZACs showed great initiative and they were so brave.
Soldiers showed initiative by running across no mans land dragging barbed wire after them.
I'll always remember the horror they would have been through, as well as family members at home non stop cooking and worrying for all the soldiers at the battle fields.
Soon I will be a future leader and I will try as hard as I can to stop war from happening.'

speech.para: Campbell Harvey of year 4 wrote the following:

quote.para: When the ANZACs went to war, the ANZACs were very scared but determined to win and fight for their country.
They showed integrity when the Turks and ANZACs worked side by side to bury the dead soldiers.
They showed loyalty and patriotism when so many soldiers signed up for the war but they did not know how horrific it would be.
We should remember the ANZACs because of all the soldiers that died for us.

speech.para: Kathleen Bernie from year 5 wrote:

quote.para: I got to the factory and I collected the material, buttons and sewing machine.
I started.
It was hard to get the jackets. I think I pricked my finger about a thousand times and I only just finished the jacket.
It was a disaster. Maybe I should try a plane building group.
Oh, thank goodness. I hated that I am on my way home and guess what?
I have been transferred to the plane building group.
Mum was sitting in her normal chair staring without blinking at Dad's chair.
She was knitting a long white frills of plaits on the end.
Who are you making the scarf for, Mum?
I am making it for your father.
When will Dad be back?, I asked.
I don't know son—for all I know he might not be coming back.
Come on, we'll have some cake and then its time for bed.
On the way to work she saw a group of kids playing in someone's back yard.
I thought: they don't even know what is happening now at the moment.
As I pulled up at the parking lot of the factory, I thought about the day working on a plane until it is done.
Then I've got to go home and do jobs around the house.
Then I walked into the plane building shed.
There were heaps of tools and metal and wire which had to be put together.
I got put on the team that put the wheels on to the other bits.
With our team we had nearly finished by the end of the day.

speech.para: Finally, Dash Moore of year 6 wrote:

quote.para: Barbed wire fences, anti tank ditches, extensive use of mine fields and the ANZAC spirit defended Tobruk.
It was on Easter that the seemingly invincible German Army attacked the fortress of Tobruk.
This attack had never failed until Tobruk.
The ANZACs waited for the troops to appear in front of the tanks then launched their weapons at the troops, then the tanks had no support and they retreated back to the German camp.
They were forced back by far less numerous Australian and British troops.
This ended the first attempt to destroy Tobruk.
Further tries were not met with success as the ANZAC spirit was too strong.
The German troops gave up after several more tries.
They had won not because they had far superior forces but because they worked as a team and their courage and pride made sure no enemy scaled Tobruk.
Courage, initiative for saving their mates and diving into battle.
Mateship, loyalty and humour for sticking with their mates and making light of a bad situation.
Their determination for getting stuck into the battle to win for their country.
The soldiers of Tobruk were great men and if anyone deserves a Victoria Cross, it was them.

speech.para: This concludes the essays. I must say how proud I am of the young people of this generation who show they are prepared to remember the deeds and trials of their forebears. It gives me great encouragement and confidence that our future generations will look after the legacy we leave them. Congratulations to all those students who wrote those stories. I am sorry I could not read them all into Hansard.

talk.start.para: —I want to talk tonight about a member of Brisbane's Southside community who has gone above and beyond the call of duty not only for our community but also for our nation. I want to talk about the life of one of the most respected residents in my local community, Robert Chester-Master, a husband, father, World War II RAAF pilot, businessman, grandfather and tireless community volunteer for the past 40 years. Robert joined the RAAF in 1943 and trained as a pilot on Tiger Moths before being posted to service training on Avro Ansons to be a bomber pilot. When a shortage of air gunners terminated the Avro Anson service training program, Robert was posted to the gunnery school. Upon completing that course, he was given the rank of sergeant and sent to Melbourne, from where he was shipped overseas in late 1943.

speech.para: Robert served as a rear gunner in Lancaster bombers in the United Kingdom and was shot down on his 13th excursion when returning from a bombing raid over Germany on 13 August 1944. Robert parachuted to safety behind enemy lines and was helped by the Belgian resistance. After hiding in various safe houses, he was eventually able to return to the UK, from where he was repatriated to Australia after being promoted to the rank of officer. Robert then served as 2IC at a transit unit in Brisbane until the end of hostilities and was discharged in December 1945. At the same time, he was awarded the KAC—the Cross of Bravery and Fidelity—by the Belgian government. Robert was recalled to active service, through the Army Reserve, from 1949 to 1956 during the Cold War. While he did not return overseas, it required continual training during this period. After serving in the RAAF, Robert worked for 42 years as the Queensland manager of three international pharmaceutical companies.

Beyond his professional life and his service career, he has also maintained active community involvement in Brisbane's Southside. Robert will be a key volunteer at the Asia Pacific Cities Summit in Brisbane, which will be held from 20 to 22 October this year. He is a committee member of the Carindale branch of National Seniors. He is secretary-treasurer of Morningside Unit One Neighbourhood Watch. He is a member of the Griffith Anzac Day Awards Committee. He is chairman of the Air Crew Association. He is the national treasurer of the Royal Air Forces Escaping Society. He is a committee member of the Caterpillar Club, which is open to members of the Air Force who were forced to bale out from their stricken aircraft. He is a committee member of the RAAF birthday service and parade each year. He is a regular guest speaker at various clubs such as Rotary, Probus and seniors groups, where he recalls what other countries did to help our RAAF personnel in times of duress.

Robert will travel to Europe in August for the commemoration of the 60th anniversary of his crash on August 13, 1944. On 12 August, the Mayor of Zottegem in Belgium will hold a civic reception in Robert's honour. That ceremony will be attended by a large number of people who were involved in the Resistance, who assisted Robert and his crew to escape, and their descendants. Regrettably, Robert is the only surviving member of the crew, and he will be representing them and their families on this occasion.

This will not be the first time that Robert has travelled back to Europe. In 1994 he returned for the 50th anniversary of the D-Day landings and in 1995 he returned for the closure of the Escaping Society in London. Robert was not planning another trip. However, at the invitation of the Patriotic Group, which was formed at the 50th anniversary of D-Day commemorations to make memorable the World War II events in Belgium, he will return for the most personal of his visits since the conclusion of the war.

At the ceremony, Robert will unveil a memorial plaque near the church where the crash occurred, in memory of those crew members with whom he served and those Belgians who helped the survivors of his crew to escape. On behalf of the Southside community, I have presented Robert with an Australian flag to use on the day. The state member for Bulimba, Pat Purcell, and the councillor for East Brisbane, Catherine Birmingham, have also donated materials for the ceremony on the day. I use this opportunity to urge the Australian Embassy in Brussels to attend and participate in this ceremony. This will be an important moment in the life of someone who has served our nation and our community well for the last 60 years.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I advise the House that on Monday, 17 May I attended a crime forum at Lemon Tree Passage Bowling Club. There were over 400 people in attendance. This is a small community and to get 400 people out on a cold Monday night means that the issue is very strong there. I would like to thank the organising committee of Peter Mason, Doreen Bradley, Shaun and Robin Brennan, Richard Osborn, Trevor and Jacki Wark, Don Barrett, Chris Somergreen, Jeff Walker, Councillor Steve Tucker and Acting Mayor Ron Swan. This committee organised a speaking panel including Col McCarthy, the president of the Raymond Terrace Police Association; Craig Jackson, the acting local area commander; of course, Acting Mayor Swan and Steve Tucker; Peter Debnam, the New South Wales shadow police minister; the Hon. Robyn Parker, who is a Liberal MLC for the area; and John Bartlett, the Labor member for Port Stephens.

speech.para: Why had the community come together? The bottom line is that the community came together to discuss the law and order problem because they do not feel secure in their own homes. In these times, not feeling secure in your own home in a country or regional area—whereas not long ago you could leave the keys in the car with it unlocked, leave your doors open and feel relatively safe—shows that we have moved in the wrong direction. In the Tilligerry Peninsula area, there are young gangs who roam the streets at night. They are mostly underage children who should be at home with their parents and in bed. At three o'clock in the morning there are kids of eight, nine, 10 and 11 years of age out roaming the streets and into alcohol, creating a mess, vandalising, destroying people's property, breaking into shops and smashing up cars—not the sorts of Australians that I am proud of.

A woman got up at the meeting and cited an example. She had saved to put some solar garden lights in her garden—19 of them. She woke up one morning and the whole 19 of them were gone. They had been stolen, smashed and dumped in Tanilba Bay. The offenders were eight, 10 and 11 years old, and this happened at 3 a.m.—a time when kids should be at home. Breaking and entering is assuming epidemic proportions. One of the issues is the delay in response, so I can understand why Eric Hixon, who owns a seafood shop at Tanilba Bay, whose shop has been burgled and damaged five times so far this year, has resorted to protecting himself with a pick handle. That was today highlighted in the Newcastle Herald in a column by Jeff Corbett.

It was only three years ago that the chamber of commerce, desperate to bring law and order and safety into this community, offered to pay for their own policing presence. No community should have to do that. Part of the problem is that, while we have a Lower Hunter area command which has 49 police and covers 8,000 square kilometres, in this area, the Tilligerry, there are 2.6 police to cover the whole of the peninsula 24 hours a day, seven days a week. That is absolutely unsatisfactory—and these police, when they are in the area, are forced to work in unsuitable premises at Lemon Tree Passage.

At the meeting the community demanded and passed resolutions: that there be an increase in policing; that there be a Port Stephens local area command formed with all of the appropriate services; and that adequate premises for policing in the region be provided. The local Labor member, John Bartlett, turned up to the meeting about an hour and a half late, relatively uninterested in what was going on, and told the community they did not need extra police. The local Labor member showed absolutely no interest in what they were doing.

There is not much I can do as a federal member in this situation, but I did announce the $20 million package for the National Community Crime Prevention Program to see what we can do to help. I have also organised for them to give evidence on 7 June at the Port Stephens council chambers at Raymond Terrace before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs headed by Bronwyn Bishop, which is running an inquiry into crime in the community.

Something needs to be done. The community need to know that their local members and politicians are not only listening but also acting on their behalf. As Peter Debnam said at the meeting, there are two types of politicians: those that are apologists for their governments and those that represent their people. John Bartlett was an apologist for the New South Wales government that failed the people, but I intend to represent the people of Paterson. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Thanks to the work of the legal profession project team of the Australian Taxation Office, almost four years ago in his annual report the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Michael Carmody, reported that a large number of members of the legal profession were rorting the tax system by repeatedly failing to lodge tax returns and then avoiding million dollar tax debts by declaring themselves bankrupt.

speech.para: On 13 February 2002 I asked the Treasurer what I assumed was a fairly straightforward question, the first question in what has now become a two-year campaign to force the government to crack down on the serial rorters of our tax system. I asked: `What percentage of (a) barristers and (b) solicitors pay the top marginal rate of income tax?' The Treasurer was in no hurry to reply, and after numerous follow-up requests to you, Mr Speaker, under standing order 150, finally I received a less than adequate reply—almost a year later—confirming that most barristers and solicitors do not even pay the top marginal rate of tax.

In October 2003 we learned that the ATO was pursuing $9.2 billion of disputed tax debt and that there were 287 cases where barristers were referred for prosecution for tax avoidance across Australia, owing $51.6 million dollars. Just 116 barristers owed $36.2 million of the total debt. Following the more than 100 questions on notice that I have asked the Treasurer, the Assistant Treasurer and the Attorney-General, we now know that, in addition to paying no tax or little tax, hundreds of barristers are not even up to date with the lodgment of their tax returns. In one celebrated example, one QC had not even lodged a tax return for 45 years. Answers to my questions also confirmed that another QC worked for the tax office for eight years and did not lodge a tax return in that period. What does that say about the ATO's ability to pursue tax cheats?

We now know that a subsequent report by the legal profession project team that initially brought to light the dishonesty of some members of the legal profession was removed from the ATO's annual report removed because its findings were political dynamite. We now know that, due to the secrecy provisions of the tax act, the taxation commissioner believes he cannot advise a peak professional body, like the Law Society or the Society of Accountants, that one of its members has been bankrupt several times and thus should be struck off—even though it becomes public knowledge when someone is declared bankrupt. This view is not shared by eminent senior counsel and former president of the Law Society, Bret Walker, who came to see me early last year. He was just as anxious to bring these tax avoiders in the legal profession to justice, because they were giving honest legal professionals a bad name.

We also now know that one taxpayer has been bankrupt 12 times. This is absolutely scandalous and makes a mockery of the intention of our bankruptcy laws. It is moral bankruptcy for a person to employ family law and bankruptcy to put one's assets out of reach of one's creditors. In most cases, the only creditor to note is the tax commissioner. This is outrageous and it means long-suffering taxpayers support tax rorters who continue to enjoy their lavish lifestyle because their spouse owns all the family assets. These parasites on our taxation system enjoy the benefits of a Medicare card at the expense of all other taxpayers, honest taxpayers like the 78,000 in my electorate of Lowe who earn less than $52,000 a year—that is 81 per cent of taxpayers in Lowe. They did not even receive a tax cut in this year's budget.

In conclusion, on 14 May 2004, the Attorney-General released an exposure draft legislation titled the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment (Anti-Avoidance and Other Measures) Bill 2004, which targets high-income earners who use bankruptcy to avoid paying debts they can afford to pay. Mr Speaker, you will doubtlessly recall that at the conclusion of last night's adjournment debate I welcomed the referral of this draft legislation to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I am very pleased to see that the chair, the member for Mackellar, has just come into the chamber. I am the deputy chair of that committee and I am sure I also speak on behalf of the chair when I encourage people to make submissions to that committee to give us the best chance once and for all to shaft the tax avoidance industry on behalf of the vast majority of honest taxpayers.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to clarify certain issues. Since I was elected in 1996 I have taken one overseas study trip. In addition, I have been a member of one parliamentary delegation. In 2000 I travelled overseas on a study tour in accordance with the established procedures. On my return I prepared a detailed report, a copy of which I now seek leave to table.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —As can be seen, I had a comprehensive program, studying important issues relevant to my work as a parliamentarian. Consistent with the guidelines and advice that I received at the time I took my then partner as my nominated spouse to accompany me. I understood that I was entitled to do so when I took the trip and this has been publicly confirmed by the Special Minister of State. However, as the House knows, there has been a great deal of media speculation, innuendo and misinformation. In these circumstances I decided on the weekend that I ought to voluntarily reimburse the total cost of my study tour. I have written to the department indicating that decision and seeking their advice on the exact sum to be paid. I completely reject the false and defamatory allegation that I knowingly sought to obtain a benefit I was not entitled to.

speech.para: Earlier this year I received an FOI request from the department seeking details of that trip and other information. I fulfilled the FOI request but sought to protect the privacy of persons other than me by having their names deleted in accordance with the usual procedure. On 14 May this year my office received a phone call from Channel 7 in Adelaide requesting an interview for a program due to be aired on 17 May. I spoke to the journalist and offered to answer his questions. I showed him a letter from the Special Minister of State indicating that my travel in 2000 was in order. I offered to provide additional details if required.

Later that day I was stunned to see a promo for the Today Tonight program, which I was subsequently advised was highly defamatory and included false claims against me and another person. I immediately sought legal advice. The other person, who had been my partner, took his own legal advice and retained counsel. An injunction was granted by Judge Bishop of the District Court of South Australia. It is a matter of public record that His Honour referred to allegations in the program as `beyond the realms of defamation'. My actions were motivated not by questions about the use of my study entitlement but by the false and defamatory material foreshadowed for the program.

My former partner took his own legal advice and acted in his own interests. Although I was not aware of this fact at the time I was in a relationship with him—indeed, I only discovered certain matters in the last few months—it is now a matter of record that he had been involved in a police investigation into a matter that occurred eight years ago. I also note that there has been some speculation about other aspects of my personal life. Although most people in the community rightly would regard this as grossly offensive, because I hold a public office I responded directly to those issues in a press release last weekend.

Those of us who are members of parliament, in whatever political interest, are honoured to be here. We work hard and inevitably this puts special demands on our personal lives. We do not complain about that because it is a privilege to serve, in my case the people of Makin. But on an occasion like this it is not unreasonable to make that point. The role of the media is an important one but we all know it is a powerful one. Australians have the right to expect accountability by MPs, but they also have the right to expect that the truth will be reported accurately and that the lowest forms of muckraking, gossip and defamation will not be the standard. As I have already indicated, I have instructed my solicitors to pursue these matters vigorously because every Australian has the right to a fair go.

In concluding, I thank my family, my many colleagues and my constituents in Makin who have supported me. They know me and they know that I am committed to the work I have taken on and to the values and the policies that I believe in and that I have always sought to bring to this parliament a high standard of personal integrity matched by my utter determination to work for the people of my electorate.
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: to present a bill for an act to amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996, and for related purposes. (Workplace Relations Amendment (Protecting Small Business Employment) Bill 2004)

to present a bill for an act to amend the law relating to social security and veterans' entitlements, and for related purposes. (Family and Community Services and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Income Streams) Bill 2004)
to move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Proposed refurbishment of ANZAC Park East and ANZAC Park West buildings and fit-out of ANZAC Park West building, Parkes, ACT.

talk.start.para: to move:

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 September 2003:

question.para: Further to the answers to questions Nos 1620 to 1635 and 1637 (Hansard, 12 August 2003, page 18283) what are the Chief Executive Officers of the Minister's departments and agencies doing to ensure that they do not retain the services of any barrister or solicitor who has previously been made bankrupt.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: In accordance with Government policy, Treasury seeks not to engage legal counsel who have used insolvency as a means of avoiding tax.

The Department can engage legal counsel both through the Australian Government Solicitor (AGS), which provides general legal services to the Department, and through private legal firms which are periodically engaged to provide legal services for specific tasks.

When engaging counsel, AGS takes into account any available information suggesting that the counsel is insolvent and informs the Department accordingly. In such cases the Department would instruct AGS to check the National Personal Insolvency Index to confirm such information. Where this information was confirmed, the Department would then instruct AGS to seek to establish whether the insolvency was attributable to an intention to avoid taxes.

In cases where private legal firms engage counsel on behalf of the Department, staff oversighting these contracts are required to notify the legal firm in question of the Government's policy not to engage legal counsel who have used insolvency as a means of avoiding tax and to instruct the firm to pursue appropriate enquiries.

The Australian Accounting Standards Board has primarily used the services of the Australian Government Solicitor to address legal issues since the AASB was established on 1 January 2000. It is presumed that the AGS staff comply with any requirements of the government in relation to their suitability and compliance with professional requirements so no specific action has been taken to review the background of the solicitor(s) involved.

The AASB has on occasion retained the services of Mallesons Stephen Jaques for legal advice. Given the large size of the firm and their professional reputation and length of time in operation, no specific action was taken to review the background of the solicitor(s) involved.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics has engaged a panel of nationally based legal firms through a public tender process.
These legal firms were subjected to independent financial viability checks prior to their appointment to the ABS panel of legal advisers.

The ACCC acquires its legal services from a panel of six national law firms. They are selected by means of a formal tendering process which, among other things, is designed to ensure the probity of successful tenderers.

Following receipt of a copy of the Attorney-General's letter of 6 March 2001 to all Ministers, each firm was formally instructed that the ACCC would not brief counsel who had been made bankrupt and that it was their obligation to ensure that any counsel who was being considered for briefing was not in fact a bankrupt. The ACCC regularly liaises with the firms and monitors this requirement as part of liaison discussions.

In retaining barristers, APRA acts in accordance with Appendix D of the Attorney-General's Legal Service Directions (`Directions on Engagement of Counsel'). We also seek advice from the Office of Legal Services Coordination (OLSC) in the Attorney-General's Department as to whether counsel under consideration have been briefed before by Commonwealth agencies and to obtain fee details. In almost all cases, APRA has briefed counsel on a list which OLSC maintains. Consistent with the Commonwealth policy, APRA is not aware of ever having briefed counsel who have used insolvency as a means of avoiding tax.

In cases where APRA is instructing the Australian Government Solicitor to act on its behalf and counsel is retained, APRA takes advice from AGS as to counsel's suitability for a particular matter. In such cases, where a particular counsel is seen as potentially suitable, AGS take into account any information which APRA provides to them or that is otherwise available to AGS suggesting that the counsel was insolvent.

ASIC is aware of Government policy that legal counsel who have used insolvency as a means of avoiding tax should not be retained on behalf of Commonwealth agencies such as ASIC. Such policy was expressed in a letter from the Attorney-General to the Treasurer dated 21 March 2001, a copy of which was forwarded to ASIC.

In accordance with Government policy ASIC will not retain a barrister or solicitor if it is aware that the barrister or solicitor has used insolvency as a means of avoiding tax. Prior to retaining counsel ASIC, as a standard procedure, contacts the Office of Legal Services Coordination (OLSC) in the Attorney-General's Department. That contact is necessary to ensure that ASIC is complying with Government policy on counsel fees. The OLSC provides ASIC with details taken from a database about the appropriate level of fees to be paid to the particular counsel proposed to be retained. ASIC understands that counsel who are known to have used insolvency as a means of avoiding tax are removed from the database.

If ASIC otherwise had reason to be concerned about the insolvency history of particular counsel it can also conduct a search by requesting the Insolvency and Trustee Service (ITSA), which is part of the Attorney-General's portfolio to examine the history of particular counsel. ASIC will then take that history into account in its decision of whether or not to retain counsel.

ASIC also notes that entry to the legal profession is a matter regulated by the States and Territories and each of the States and Territories has laws and regulations dealing with legal practitioners who have committed acts of bankruptcy.

In the majority of cases, the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) retains its barristers through the office of the Australian Government Solicitor (AGS). In such instances, the ATO is reliant on the checking processes utilised by AGS. AGS engages Counsel consistently with the requirements set out in the Legal Services Directions issued by the Attorney General's Department pursuant to section 55ZF of the Judiciary Act.
The directions do not identify steps which a Commonwealth agency or its lawyers can take to enquire that barristers have not used bankruptcy as a means of avoiding taxation obligations.

Wherever possible, AGS relies on existing knowledge of a barrister's reputation and, in particular, that the barrister has not used bankruptcy as a means of avoiding taxation obligations. Similarly, in those instances where the ATO directly briefs a barrister, the ATO relies on prior knowledge of the barrister's reputation that they have not used bankruptcy as a means of avoiding taxation obligations.

The Commissioner is currently seeking advice from the Attorney-General's Department about the circumstances in which it would be appropriate not to engage a barrister or solicitor who has previously been made bankrupt, and also about the means by which the Commissioner can obtain reliable information about whether a barrister or solicitor has previously been made bankrupt.
The Corporations and Markets Advisory Committee does not retain the services of any barrister or solicitor.

The National Competition Council engages barristers and solicitors on the basis of their qualifications and experience, and suitability to represent the Council in the matter concerned. The Council has no specific prohibition against retaining Counsel who have been previously made bankrupt, but it is unlikely that such a person would be considered suitable to represent the Council.
All Solicitors/Barristers briefed are checked before we engage them.

Since 1999 the Productivity Commission has sought legal advice exclusively from the Australian Government Solicitor whose employees are taken as meeting the necessary standards of professionalism. If the Commission has cause to seek advice beyond the Australian Government Solicitor, it would take the necessary steps to satisfy itself as to the professionalism of the legal service provider.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2387 (Hansard, 1 December 2003, page 23084), can he explain how the provisions of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 work with the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act to ensure the early detection and prosecution of tax defaulters so that it does not take up to forty years to convict such a person.

(2) If the provisions of the two Acts do not complement each other so as to ensure the early detection and prosecution of tax defaulters, what action is he taking to align the provisions of the Bankruptcy Act to support tax policy to prevent tax defaulters enjoying a tax free life for forty years without apparent detection.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The provisions of the Bankruptcy Act only apply when a taxpayer is insolvent and are designed to distribute the assets of such a taxpayer amongst the taxpayer's creditors. Upon detection of tax defaulters, the Commissioner of Taxation may institute prosecution action through the Tax Administration Act 1953.
(2) The early detection and prosecution of tax defaulters is not a function of the Bankruptcy Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2277 (Hansard, 1 December 2003, page 23079), in respect of CLERP 9, within those reform proposals dealing with auditor qualifications, independence and services, what provisions in CLERP 9, if any, require an auditor or a person bearing that title to be a qualified accountant.
(2) Which recommendations within CLERP 9 will ensure the prevention of auditing failures such as the collapse of the HIH and FAI Insurance group.
(3) What provisions specifically deal with defective auditing procedures being performed by persons who are not qualified accountants.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Corporate Law Economic Reform Program (Audit Reform and Corporate Disclosure) Bill 2003 (CLERP 9 Bill) provides that an individual, a firm or a company may be appointed auditor of a company or a registered scheme for the purposes of the Corporations Act 2001. In each case, the natural person responsible for the conduct of a particular audit must be a registered company auditor.

The Corporations Act provides that the Australian Securities and Investments Commission must not register a natural person as a company auditor unless the applicant holds a degree, diploma or certificate from a prescribed university or another prescribed institution in Australia and has, in the course of obtaining that degree, diploma or certificate, completed a course of study in accountancy (including auditing) of not less than 3 years duration and in commercial law (including company law) of not less than 2 years duration.

(2) The Government notes that a number of factors contributed to the failure of HIH and FAI and that it is not possible to guarantee through regulatory means that no company will fail. However, the CLERP 9 Bill contains measures, including enhanced requirements about independence of auditors, disclosures about provision of non-audit services, revised requirements for the registration of company auditors and giving auditing standards the force of law, which, taken together, will provide capital market participants with a high level of confidence in the independence of the auditor and the auditor's report on the financial statements.

(3) The legislative provisions underpinning the revised auditing requirements provide that the natural person responsible for the conduct of an audit is to be a registered company auditor. The CLERP 9 Bill sets criminal penalties for people who consent to be appointed auditor, act as auditor or prepare an audit report if they are not a registered company auditor.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer upon, notice, on 1 March 2004 :

question.para: (1) Can the Minister indicate (a) whether the Minister's department has a dedicated Freedom of Information (FOI) officer, and (b) how many officers are employed to deal with FOI requests, and (c) at what levels they are employed.
(2) How many applications did the department have under the FOI Act in the 2002-2003 financial year and how did this figure compare to previous years.
(3) How many internal reviews of applications occurred in the last financial year and how many internal reviews affirmed the original decision.
(4) Can the information in (2) and (3) be broken down into applications requesting individual information and applications requesting information for other reasons (i.e. media, opposition MPs etc).
(5) What proportion of cases go to external review and what proportion of these are upheld.
(6) In respect of fees for FOI applications, (a) how much was charged, (b) how much was actually collected, and (c) what proportion of fees were waived.
(7) How much did the Minister's department spend in defending FOI appeals.

(8) In respect of refusals to grant requests, can the Minister provide details on (a) which exemption categories are used when information is refused, and (b) what proportion of refusals are in each category (i.e. commercial-in-confidence and other categories).

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Yes it does.

(b) and (c) Precise figures can not be provided as each request involves different officers from different areas, such as the General Manager of the relevant policy area who is delegated to make decisions. It could not be said that these officers are employed to deal with FOI requests.

(2) The information for the 2002-2003 financial year is found in the Annual Report by the Attorney-General to the Parliament on the Operation of the Freedom of Information Act 1982 (2002-2003) (FOI Annual Report), Appendix A. Comparisons to previous years may be made by reference to information in previous FOI Annual Reports.
(3) This information is found in the FOI Annual Report, Appendix E.
(4) This information is found in the FOI Annual Report, Appendix A.
(5) This information is found in the FOI Annual Report, Appendix F and G.
(6) (a) & (b) This information is found in the FOI Annual Report, Appendix D.
(c) Approximately $150 were waived in fees.
(7) This information is found in the FOI Annual Report, Appendix L.
(8) (a) and (b) The FOI Act does not require that this information be collected and an answer can not be provided without an unreasonable diversion of resources.
(9) The FOI Act does not require that this information be collected. Collation of such statistics over the last 5 years would require an unreasonable diversion of resources.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 10 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Does he recall telling the House on 18 June 2003 “The fact is that there will be more than 2,500 individual offices operating around Australia that are going to provide employment services to Australia's jobseekers.”

(2) Could he outline how many of these offices provide the full-suite of Job Network services (Job Matching, Job Search Training and Intensive Support Customised Assistance); NEIS; Harvest Labour Services; and Job Placement Services.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, there are currently more than 2,500 individual offices providing employment services to jobseekers at locations around Australia.

(2) Under the third employment services contract which commenced on 1 July 2003, significant changes have been made to employment services delivery arrangements, which are already delivering the best performance results in the history of either the Job Network or the CES.

Under the new arrangements Job Network organisations are contracted to provide Job Search Support and Intensive Support Services. These organisations are also licensed to provide Job Placement Services. In addition, there are a number of organisations licensed to provide Job Placement Services only, or contracted to provide services under NEIS (New Enterprise Incentive Scheme) or Harvest Labour Services. These employment services were tendered and purchased separately, albeit at the same time. They are separate services to Job Search Support and Intensive Support notwithstanding they are appropriated under Job Network.

There is no instance of any individual service site providing all of the employment services, which is consistent with previous arrangements. However, there are more sites than ever before that provide the comprehensive Job Network service.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (i) The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade received all the ONA and DIO reports which are the subject of this question, except for the ONA assessment of 20 September 2002 (Q. 9) and the DIO assessment of 24 February 2003 (Q. 25) which the Department has no record of receiving. The reports were received on, or within a few days of, the date of their issue.

With regard to (Q. 1), ONA has advised that the report referred to at paragraph 2.3 of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD Report on Intelligence on Iraq's Weapons of Mass Destruction was issued on 16 February 2000, not 16 February 2002.
(ii) I have been assured that all reports received by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade were appropriately distributed within the Department.
ONA and DIO assessments are delivered separately to the Minister's Office by the agencies.

ONA and DIO assessments, and, to a lesser extent, material received from other intelligence agencies, are one of several sources of information taken into account in the policy formulation process. DFAT policy advice draws extensively on information from other sources, including diplomatic reporting and other information in the public domain.
I have delivered a number of speeches referring to Iraq. These are on the public record.

The preparation of ministerial speeches is, on most occasions, a collaborative effort between my Office and my Department. A range of policy advice was used in the preparation of the ministerial speeches. Where specific intelligence material was used, the details of particular references were cleared by the Australian Intelligence Community.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of his statement to the House on 17 September 2002 in which he said “Australian intelligence agencies believe there is evidence of a pattern of acquisition of equipment that could be used in a uranium enrichment program. Iraq's attempted acquisition of very specific types of aluminium tubes may be part of that pattern”, was this statement contained in an Office of National Assessments (ONA) or a Defence Intelligence Organisation (DIO) report received by his department at that time; if so, was the assessment underlying the claim explicitly cleared by ONA or DIO.
(2) When was advice sent to him discounting or ruling out this claim.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) My statement is consistent with assessments contained in the unclassified compendium of 13 September produced by ONA with assistance from other Australian intelligence agencies. It is also consistent with the Joint Report ONA produced with DIO which is quoted in ONA's submission to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD Report on Intelligence on Iraq's Weapons of Mass Destruction.
(2) No ONA advice has subsequently been sent to me discounting or ruling out the claim.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of his statement on Lateline on 18 July 2002 in which he said “I don't think there is any doubt about Saddam Hussein having stockpiles of biological and chemical weapons...there is a very grave concern that he's been enhancing those stockpiles in recent years”, was this statement contained in an Office of National Assessments (ONA) or a Defence Intelligence Organisation (DIO) report received by his department at that time; if so, did ONA or DIO assessments contain a reference to the `grave concern' he referred to.

(2) Was the ONA assessment of 6 September referred to in paragraph 2.5 of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO, ASIS and DSD Report on Intelligence on Iraq's Weapons of Mass Destruction which stated that intelligence on Iraq is “slight on the scope and location of Iraq's WMD activities”, brought to the attention of his office; if so, when did this occur and in what form did the advice take.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I took a number of sources into account, including DIO and ONA assessments when appropriate, in making statements regarding Iraq and WMD. It is not the Government's practice to disclose the contents of classified ONA and DIO assessments.
(2) ONA and DIO assessments are delivered separately to the Minister's Office by the agencies. The Department has no knowledge of the details of these deliveries.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 2004:

quote.para: In respect of his claim made during an interview at Adelaide Airport on 10 March 2003 in which he said “our assessment is that there is a real risk of weapons of mass destruction being transferred from rogue states, not from responsible states, not from France or China or the United States or Britain or Russia, but from rogue states into the hands of terrorists”, was the specific risk he referred to cited in an Office of National Assessments or a Defence Intelligence Organisation report received by his department; if so (a) what was the date of the report, and (b) when was it conveyed to his office; if not, (c) was the risk he referred to in any other advice he received from his department, and (d) what was the source of this advice.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: I took a broad range of sources into account, including advice my department provided on several occasions, and DIO and ONA assessments when appropriate, in making statements regarding WMD. It is not the Government's practice to disclose the contents of classified ONA and DIO assessments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 March 2004:

question.para: (1) What are the protocols to be followed by Members and Senators wishing to visit Australian defence establishments.
(2) What criteria does the Minister use to determine whether a request to visit a defence establishment is approved or denied.

(3) In respect of each instance a Member of the Commonwealth Parliament has sought approval to visit a defence establishment since 1 January 2002, (a) which Member or Senator sought approval, (b) which defence establishment was the subject of the request, (c) how long after the first receipt of the request by the Minister's office was a decision made, (d) was the request approved or rejected, and (e) where approval was given, was it conditional on any matters; if so what were the conditions.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) Protocols relating to visits by parliamentarians to Defence establishments, which have been in place since the early 1990s, are listed below and state where approval by the Minister for Defence is required. In cases where approval is required, a minimum of seven working days' notice should be given by parliamentarians for proposed visits to individual establishments and ten working days for visits to more than one establishment.
Constituency Visits

These visits are undertaken by a local member or senator on constituency business only. Such visits may concern the establishment's relationships with, and responsibilities in, the local community, or for the member or senator being available to constituents for discussion of personal matters affecting them as citizens. These visits do not require the approval of the Minister for Defence.
Ceremonial Visits

These visits include graduation parades, ceremonial events (for example, ships' open days, trooping the colour, award presentations) and invitations to dine or other purely social events. These visits do not require the approval of the Minister for Defence.
Official Visits

These visits are those involving official openings of buildings or facilities, familiarisation tours, briefings and speaking engagements (other than those connected with a ceremonial visit). Official visits require the written approval of the Minister for Defence.

There may be a need for parliamentarians to make prior contact with the establishment concerned to arrive at a mutually-convenient date for the proposed visit. Such contact should not extend to matters of itinerary or program detail in advance of the Minister's agreement to the proposed visit.
Visits to Intelligence Establishments
Visits to such establishments require the approval of the Minister for Defence, even where the visit is intended for constituency or ceremonial reasons.
(3) Defence does not maintain a dedicated record of visit requests by parliamentarians and is unable to devote the considerable time and resources to manually collate such a list.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 March 2004:

quote.para: Is he able to say whether there has been any reduction in the capacity of the Government of (a) Indonesia, (b) Malaysia, (c) Papua-New Guinea, (d) The Philippines, and (e) Singapore to devote resources to combating criminal and illicit activity in its maritime border since 1997; if so, (i) what was the cause of that decline, (ii) has that decline been remedied, and (iii) what steps, if any, has Australia taken to assist that country to police its maritime borders and territorial waters.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: It would be inappropriate for Australia to make specific comments on regional countries' maritime surveillance capabilities. While the capacity of some countries in the region to devote resources may have been reduced as a result of the financial crisis in the late 1990s, to my knowledge, there has not been an overall reduction in capacity between 1997 and the present time.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 March 2004:

quote.para: Has he, or has anyone on his behalf, had discussions with a representative or representatives of the Government of (a) Indonesia, (b) Malaysia, (c) Papua-New Guinea, (d) The Philippines, and (e) Singapore in respect of assisting that country to police its maritime borders and territorial waters in respect of (i) pro-active intelligence exchange, (ii) the provision of coastal surveillance technologies, (iii) the institution of joint patrols, and (iv) the establishment of common communication technology.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Australian Government - its Ministers and Officials - has had a range of discussions with all the above countries on maritime security cooperation. We have signed MOUs on CT cooperation with the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia and PNG. The Government's $10 million CT package of assistance to Indonesia includes a special travel security fund (STFS). Through the STFS, we are working with Indonesia to build its border management capacity. We are also assisting Indonesia and PNG to comply with their obligations under the IMO's International Ship and Port Facility Security Code (ISPS) requirements by 1 July 2004. Similarly, as part of a $5M CT package of assistance to the Philippines, the Department of Transport and Communications has held discussions with a number of Philippine authorities on a project aimed at building the capacity of Philippine port authorities to develop and implement port security plans to assist it in meeting its obligations under the ISPS.

answer.para: (i) Australian Government agencies conduct intelligence exchanges with their counterpart agencies in all five countries, including on matters relating to maritime security.

(ii) Through our Defence Cooperation Program with Indonesia, Australia provides assistance to the Indonesian Navy to support its fleet of Nomad maritime surveillance aircraft. This assistance is through the posting of a 3 person Nomad Maintenance Team. The Team assists the Indonesian Nomad fleet by assuring airworthiness, delivering on-the-job training and establishing a maintenance program. The AFP provides on-going training in technical surveillance matters to the Royal Malaysian Police Special Branch to support all facets of police activity, especially maritime border protection and the movement of persons between Southern Philippines and East Malaysia. In 2000, the Government approved a life extension program to ensure 22 Pacific class patrol boats Austrlaia provided to Pacific Island countries, including 4 operated by PNG, remain effective for a further 15 years.

(iii) No. However, Australian, Singaporean and Malaysian navies undertake joint exercises periodically under the Five Power Defence Arrangements (FPDA) together with the United Kingdom and New Zealand. Under the Defence Cooperation Program with PNG Australia assists PNG to police its maritime and territorial waters. A Royal Australian Navy Officer has been placed in PNG's National Coordination Centre. Regular joint exercises with PNG covering the principles of maritime border surveillance are also held regularly (eg Exercise Paradise in November 2002). Australian Customs supports regular cross-border patrols with PNG approximately 4 times per year. We have also provided two boats to the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary in Sandaun Province to assist with their operations along the PNG/Indonesia border.
(iv) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 March 2004:

quote.para: Since 1 April 1996, what discussions has he had or has anyone on his behalf had with a representative or representatives of the Government of (a) Indonesia, (b) Malaysia, (c) Papua-New Guinea, (d) The Philippines, and (e) Singapore addressing (i) piracy, (ii) unsolicited migration, (iii) the movement of narcotics, and (iv) the movement of guns; if discussions have occurred, when did the discussions occur, who were the discussions between, and what was the outcome of the discussions.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Since April 1996, I and officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have had numerous discussions with Ministers and officials of the Governments of Indonesia, Malaysia, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines and Singapore, on transnational crime issues. These discussions have been both bilateral and multilateral. The most significant discussions on illegal migration have occurred at the two Regional Ministerial Conferences on People Smuggling, Trafficking in Persons and Related Transnational Crime, co-chaired by Australia and Indonesia and held in Bali on 26-28 February 2002 and 28-30 April 2003. I co-chaired both Bali Conferences with my Indonesian counterpart, Dr Hassan Wirajuda. Ministers from Malaysia, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines and Singapore participated in the first Bali Conference at Ministerial level; and except for the Philippines (which was represented at Senior Officials level) all others were represented at Ministerial level at the second Conference. The Bali Conferences each produced a Co-Chair's statement, which have been used to take forward a program of practical activities in the region aimed at combating people smuggling, trafficking in persons and related transnational crime.

The AFP is coordinating the development of the $38.3 million Jakarta Centre for Law Enforcement Cooperation (JCLEC). The key objective of the JCLEC will be to enhance the operational expertise of the regional law enforcement personnel in dealing with transnational crime, with a primary focus on enhancing counter-terrorism skills. While the JCLEC will be an Indonesia facility, it will be significantly supported and substantially funded by Australia. Australia is also funding the establishment of a Transnational Crime Coordination Centre within Indonesia's National Police (POLRI) to support Indonesian efforts in combating transnational organised crime activities.

The AFP/POLRI Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on Combating Transnational Crime and Developing Police Cooperation provides a framework for on-going cooperation in preventing, investigating, disrupting and dismantling transnational crime activity, including narcotics and drug trafficking. In 2003, Australia delivered 5 small coastal patrol boats to Indonesia's National Police (POLRI).

Australia and the Philippines have an MOUs on Counter-Terrorism and another on Transnational Crime matters. The first was signed by then Philippines Foreign Secretary Blas Ople and me in March 2003; the second is between the AFP and the Philippines National Police, Philippines Drug Enforcement Agency and the Philippines Bureau of Investigations signed in July 2003.

Australia and PNG entered a new era of cooperation at the annual Ministerial Forum in December 2003. The Enhanced Cooperation Program agreed by Ministers includes a central component designed to strengthen PNG's capacity to manage borders. Separately, Australia and PNG concluded an MOU on Migration, Refugees and People Smuggling in July 2003. Australia has also held a number of courses for PNG Government officials (including on people smuggling, organised crime and narcotics), established a bilateral transnational crime team as part of a South Pacific regional initiative, and through Australian Customs regularly conducts Joint Cross-border Patrols with PNG.

Throughout the period in question, the AFP liaison officers at Australian Missions in Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Philippines and PNG have liaised with local authorities on various transnational crime issues. Australian Airport Liaison Officers stationed in Kuala Lumpur and Singapore have regular exchanges of information with Malaysian and Singaporean authorities on interception of illegal migrants.
